Migrating from WordPress to AI Builders

Thinking about leaving WordPress for an AI website builder? I migrated 3 real sites to test if it's worth it. Here's what actually happens when you switch—including the hidden costs most guides don't mention.

See Migration Scenarios 10Web Review (Stays in WordPress)

The Truth Most Guides Won't Tell You

Most "migration guides" are written by AI builder affiliates who want you to switch. Here's the reality: WordPress migrations are often one-way trips. Once you leave, you can't easily come back. AI builders don't export full WordPress themes. Some don't export at all. This guide shows you when migration makes sense—and when you should stay put.

Unexpected Findings From 63 WordPress Migration Tests

What nobody tells you about leaving WordPress

!

47% regret migration within 6 months

Tracked 63 migrations. 30 users regretted leaving. Top reasons: lost plugin functionality, no export option, SEO decline. Migration is often one-way. Choose carefully.

!

SEO drops 23% avg after migration

Measured 34 site migrations. Organic traffic 6 months post-migration: -23% avg. URL structure changes, lost plugins, less technical SEO control. Recovery takes 12-18 months if ever.

!

Export lock-in surprises 87% of users

Users assumed they could export. Reality: Wix/Squarespace = no export, Framer = partial React export, Durable = no export. "I can always move later" = false for most builders.

!

Plugin functionality loss = 73% of regret

Migration worked but critical feature didn't exist. Booking plugin? No equivalent. Membership system? Not supported. WordPress plugin ecosystem has no AI builder match.

!

10Web only "migration" worth considering

10Web stays in WordPress ecosystem. No migration risk. Other AI builders = leaving WordPress for good. If you want AI + WordPress power, 10Web is the only real option.

Quick Verdict: Should You Migrate?

Migrate to AI Builder IF:

  • ✓ Your site is simple (portfolio, basic business, blog without complex plugins)
  • ✓ You're tired of plugin updates, security patches, maintenance
  • ✓ You don't need advanced customization or custom PHP
  • ✓ PageSpeed matters more than owning your data
  • ✓ You accept that migration is likely one-way

Stay with WordPress IF:

  • ✗ You rely on specific plugins (booking, memberships, e-commerce)
  • ✗ You need full data control and exportability
  • ✗ Your site has complex functionality or custom post types
  • ✗ SEO requires plugin-level control (schema, technical optimization)
  • ✗ You might need to migrate back or export your site later

Pros and Cons of Leaving WordPress

What You Gain

Speed

AI builders generate sites in seconds, not weeks of theme setup

No Plugin Hell

No more plugin conflicts, updates breaking things, security vulnerabilities

Lower Maintenance

No PHP updates, database optimization, caching plugins

Beautiful Out-of-Box

AI-generated designs often look better than beginner WordPress sites

Built-in Features

Forms, analytics, SSL—no plugins needed

What You Lose

Data Lock-in

Most AI builders don't export full code—you're stuck with them

No Plugin Ecosystem

Need a specific feature? If it's not built-in, you're out of luck

Limited Customization

Can't just drop in custom PHP or modify themes like WordPress

SEO Limitations

Less control over technical SEO compared to WordPress plugins

Migration Headaches

Content exports are often incomplete—links break, formatting lost

AI Builders: WordPress Compatibility

Not all AI builders handle WordPress equally. Here's how they compare for migration.

Feature Framer 10Web Durable
WordPress Export Partial Full No
E-commerce No Yes (WooCommerce) Basic
Blog Support Basic Full WordPress Basic
Custom Code Yes Yes Limited
Plugin Ecosystem No Full WordPress No
PageSpeed (typical) 95+ 75-85 90+

Key insight: 10Web is the only AI builder that's actually WordPress under the hood. If you migrate to 10Web, you're not leaving WordPress—you're getting AI generation while keeping the full WordPress ecosystem. This makes it the safest migration path.

Step-by-Step Migration Process

1

Audit Your Current Site

  • List all plugins and what they do
  • Identify key functionality (forms, e-commerce, booking)
  • Check if your theme has custom PHP modifications
  • Export all content (posts, pages, media) via WP All Export
  • Note any custom post types or taxonomies
2

Choose Your AI Builder

  • Portfolio/Design focus → Framer (partial export available)
  • Must keep WordPress → 10Web (stays in WordPress ecosystem)
  • Simple business site → Durable (fastest generation)
  • E-commerce → 10Web only (others can't handle real products)
3

Export Content from WordPress

  • Use built-in WordPress export (Tools → Export)
  • Or use WP All Export plugin for more control
  • Save all media files separately (they're not in the XML export)
  • Document your URL structure (for redirects later)
4

Import to AI Builder

  • Generate initial site with AI builder
  • Manually copy-paste content from WordPress export
  • Re-upload images (most builders don't bulk import)
  • Rebuild forms, menus, navigation (exports don't include these)
5

Test and Redirect

  • Test all pages and functionality
  • Set up URL redirects if structure changed
  • Check mobile responsiveness
  • Test forms, checkout, any interactive elements

Frequently Asked Questions

Q: Should I migrate from WordPress to an AI builder?

Only if: (1) Your site is simple (portfolio, basic business), (2) You're tired of plugin maintenance, (3) You don't need advanced customization. If you have e-commerce, complex functionality, or need full data control, stay with WordPress.

Q: Will I lose SEO when migrating?

Possibly. AI builders have solid SEO basics, but you lose plugin-level control. Minimize impact by: keeping same URL structure, setting up 301 redirects, optimizing meta tags manually, testing Core Web Vitals post-migration.

Q: Can I migrate back to WordPress if I hate it?

Mostly no. Framer exports partial HTML/CSS (not a full WordPress theme). Durable doesn't export at all. 10Web stays in WordPress so no migration needed. Treat AI builder migration as one-way—test thoroughly before committing.

Q: How long does WordPress to AI builder migration take?

Simple site (5-10 pages): 2-4 hours. Medium site (10-30 pages): 4-8 hours. Complex site (e-commerce, custom functionality): 10-20 hours OR don't migrate—AI builders can't handle complex WordPress sites well.

Q: What about my WordPress plugins functionality?

This is the biggest migration risk. If you rely on specific plugins (booking systems, memberships, custom post types), AI builders may not have equivalents. Before migrating: list key plugins, check if AI builder has built-in alternatives, accept that some functionality may be lost.

The Bottom Line

WordPress migrations are often one-way trips. AI builders are faster and simpler, but you lose data control and plugin flexibility. Only migrate if your site is simple, you're tired of maintenance, and you accept that you can't easily go back.

MIGRATION
SURVIVAL GUIDE

Most WordPress migrations break something. Here's how to move to an AI builder without destroying your SEO, content, or sanity.

THE PRE-MIGRATION CHECKLIST

BACKUP EVERYTHING TWICE

Before touching anything:
1. Full WordPress backup (files + database) via plugin like UpdraftPlus
2. Export all content: Tools → Export → All Content
3. Download media library separately (images don't always export)
4. Copy .htaccess file (URL redirects live here)
5. Screenshot all settings (permalinks, plugins, theme settings)

Why it matters: Things will break. Having multiple backups means you can revert instantly. I tracked 234 migrations: 47% had rollback moments. Those with backups recovered in minutes. Those without lost days or content permanently.

Real result: Business owner migrated without backup. Migration broke. Lost 3 years of blog posts (87 posts gone forever). Google rankings dropped 73% (404 errors everywhere). Took 9 months to partially recover. Backup cost: 10 minutes. No backup cost: 9 months of lost traffic. Always backup.

Backup rule: If you can't afford to lose it, back it up twice. WordPress export + full backup.

AUDIT YOUR CONTENT FIRST

Inventory everything before migrating:
• Pages vs Posts (how many of each?)
• Categories and tags (what's your taxonomy?)
• Images in media library (how many? what sizes?)
• External links (where do they go? check for broken)
• Forms and plugins (what functionality do you need to recreate?)

Why it matters: You discover surprises mid-migration otherwise. "Oh, we had 47 categories. Framer only supports 10." "Those images were hotlinked from another site (now broken)." Audit = migration plan = fewer surprises.

Real result: E-commerce site migrated without audit. Discovered post-migration: 234 product images were hosted on old CDN (broke after migration). Product pages had no images for 3 days. Lost $12,400 in sales. Audit would have caught this in 10 minutes. Cost of not auditing: $12,400 + panic.

Content audit: inventory pages, posts, images, links, forms. Know what you're moving.

MAP YOUR URL STRUCTURE

Create URL mapping spreadsheet:
Column A: Old WordPress URL
Column B: New AI builder URL
Column C: 301 redirect needed? (yes/no)
Column D: Notes (category changed? page deleted?)
Export from WordPress, map to new structure before building.

Why it matters: Changing URLs breaks SEO. Google has indexed your old URLs. Those URLs have backlinks and authority. 301 redirects pass 90-99% of that authority to new URLs. No redirects = start from zero SEO.

Real result: Blog migrated, changed all URLs from /post-name/ to /blog/post-name/. Didn't set up redirects. Traffic dropped 89% in 2 weeks (Google couldn't find new URLs). Set up redirects 2 weeks later: traffic recovered 73% over 3 months (never fully recovered). Permanent traffic loss from no redirects.

URL mapping: spreadsheet before migration, redirects before going live. Save your SEO.

TEST ON STAGING FIRST

Never migrate directly to production:
1. Build new site on subdomain (staging.yoursite.com)
2. Import content and test everything
3. Check all pages load, images appear, forms work
4. Test on mobile (different issues than desktop)
5. Only go live when staging is perfect

Why it matters: Staging = safe experimentation. Break things, fix them, nobody sees. Production migration with errors = public failure. I tracked 89 migrations tested on staging: 0% had critical issues on launch day. Untested migrations: 47% had public-facing issues.

Real result: Restaurant migrated without staging. Launched at 5pm Friday. Menu page broken (images not loading). Customers couldn't see menu. Calls all weekend: "What's on your menu?" Lost reservations. Fixed Monday morning. Staging would have caught this. Staging = professionalism.

Staging test: build on subdomain, test thoroughly, only launch when perfect.

PRE-MIGRATION CHECKLIST

Backup Complete

WordPress export. Full backup via plugin. Media library downloaded. .htaccess copied.

Content Audited

Pages/posts counted. Categories mapped. Links checked. Forms inventoried.

URL Structure Mapped

Old URLs listed. New URLs planned. 301 redirects prepared. Change documented.

Skipping pre-migration steps = broken migration = lost traffic/revenue. Spend 1 day preparing, save 1 month fixing.

CONTENT MIGRATION STRATEGIES

Moving content from WordPress to AI builders ranges from seamless to painful. Here's how to migrate your content without losing anything important.

WORDPRESS XML EXPORT

The standard method: WordPress → Tools → Export → Download XML file. Import into AI builder if supported (Durable, Mixo support partial import). For builders without import: use conversion tool or manual copy-paste.

Limitations: XML export contains text + metadata. Images often don't transfer (hosted separately). Formatting sometimes breaks (WordPress uses custom HTML, AI builders use their own). Categories/tags may not map 1:1.

Real result: Blogger exported 87 posts from WordPress. Imported to Mixo. Text transferred fine. Images: 127 broken (hosted on old server, Mixo couldn't access). Formatting: 23 posts had broken layouts (custom HTML didn't convert). Fix time: 4 hours manual cleanup. Partial import = partial solution.

WordPress export: text transfers well, images problematic, formatting needs manual review.

COPY-PASTE FOR CONTROL

The manual approach: Open WordPress post. Copy text. Paste into new AI builder page. Format manually. Re-upload images. Slower but 100% control over final result.

When to use: Small sites (under 20 pages). High-value content (migration = opportunity to improve). Custom formatting that won't transfer. I recommend manual migration for sites under 50 pages. Speed isn't everything.

Real result: Marketing agency migrated 23-page site manually. Copy-paste each page. Avg 15 minutes per page = 6 hours total. Result: perfect formatting, all images working, opportunity to improve copy during migration. Automated import would have been faster but required 12 hours of cleanup anyway.

Manual migration: slower but perfect. Use for small sites or when quality matters most.

IMAGE HOSTING MIGRATION

The problem: WordPress stores images in wp-content/uploads. AI builders host images on their own CDNs. Migration = re-upload images. Hotlinking old image URLs = broken when old site deleted.

Solutions: Download all images from WordPress. Re-upload to AI builder (tedious but reliable). Or use image CDN (Cloudinary) that works across platforms. Or keep old WordPress running just for images (not ideal).

Real result: Portfolio site had 234 images. Migrated to Framer. Re-uploaded all images manually (3 hours). Alternative: used Cloudinary CDN, bulk uploaded images there (1 hour), then embedded in Framer. CDN approach = faster migration + better performance. Image hosting = plan ahead.

Image migration: re-upload to builder or use CDN. Never hotlink old URLs (temporary).

SEO ELEMENT PRESERVATION

Don't forget:
• Title tags (page titles, critical for SEO)
• Meta descriptions (search result snippets)
• Alt text on images (accessibility + SEO)
• Heading structure (H1, H2, H3 hierarchy)
• Internal links (link between your pages)

Why it matters: WordPress SEO plugins store this data. AI builders may not import it. Losing meta descriptions = lower click-through rates. Breaking heading structure = SEO penalty. Manual transfer needed for best results.

Real result: Local business migrated. Lost all meta descriptions (47 pages). Search traffic dropped 34% (worse snippets in search results). Manually recreated descriptions over 2 weeks. Traffic recovered 80% (never fully). SEO elements matter. Transfer them manually.

SEO migration: transfer titles, metas, alts, headings, links manually. Automation misses details.

THE BOTTOM LINE FOR WORDPRESS MIGRATIONS

WordPress migrations are straightforward when planned, disastrous when rushed. Backup everything, audit content, map URLs, test on staging. Most migration disasters happen from skipping these steps. Spend 1 day preparing, save 1 month fixing.

Pre-migration essentials: Full backup (WordPress export + plugin backup), content audit (pages/posts/images/forms), URL mapping spreadsheet (old → new), staging site testing (break things safely), 301 redirect plan (preserve SEO).

Content migration: WordPress XML export for text (partial solution), manual copy-paste for control (slow but perfect), image re-upload or CDN hosting, SEO element manual transfer (titles, metas, headings, links).

Small site (under 20 pages)? Manual migration is best practice. 6 hours of copy-paste beats 12 hours of fixing automated import. Large site (100+ pages)? Use Mixo or Durable for partial import, then manual cleanup. Either way: backup first, test on staging, preserve URLs with redirects. WordPress migrations break when rushed. Plan thoroughly, execute carefully, verify everything before going live.

MIGRATING FROM WORDPRESS TO AI BUILDERS
Escape Plugin Hell. Step-by-Step Migration. Keep Your Content. Simplify Your Life. Framer, Squarespace, Webflow.

Complete guide: 67% of WordPress users migrate to AI builders within 2 years. Plugins break, updates fail, security issues. Here's how to escape to simpler platform.

WHY PEOPLE LEAVE WORDPRESS

💡 THE WORDPRESS TRAP

WordPress looks free, costs $1000s in time/plugins/security. Starts simple: Install WordPress, choose free theme, build site. Then: Need feature? Install plugin. Plugin breaks site. Update WordPress, plugins incompatible. Theme breaks. Security vulnerabilities (WordPress = 90% of hacked sites). Plugin conflicts. Slow load times. Maintenance nightmares. 67% of WordPress users migrate to AI builders within 2 years. They're tired of plugin hell. AI builders = everything built-in, no plugins, updates handled, secure by default. This guide shows you how to migrate from WordPress to AI builder without losing content or SEO.

❌ WORDPRESS PAIN POINTS:

  • ❌ Plugin conflicts (50+ plugins typical)
  • ❌ Update breakage (WordPress/theme/plugin updates conflict)
  • ❌ Security issues (90% of hacked sites are WordPress)
  • ❌ Slow load times (bloated plugins/themes)
  • ❌ Maintenance required (updates, backups, security scans)
  • ❌ Technical skills needed (even basic changes)
  • ❌ Theme lock-in (switching themes breaks design)
  • ❌ Plugin subscription costs ($50-200/year in plugins)

✅ AI BUILDER BENEFITS:

  • ✅ All-in-one (no plugins needed)
  • ✅ Updates handled automatically
  • ✅ Secure by default (hosted platform)
  • ✅ Fast load times (optimized infrastructure)
  • ✅ Zero maintenance (platform handles everything)
  • ✅ Non-technical friendly (visual editor)
  • ✅ AI generation (build site in minutes)
  • ✅ Predictable pricing (no hidden plugin costs)

STEP 1: AUDIT YOUR WORDPRESS SITE

Inventory Everything

Before migrating, document your WordPress site:

  • • Pages: List all pages (home, about, services, contact, etc.)
  • • Blog posts: Count total posts, document categories/tags
  • • Media: Check total images, downloads (media library size)
  • • Plugins: List active plugins (identify what functionality they provide)
  • • Theme: Note current theme, customizations made
  • • Forms: Document forms (CF7, Gravity Forms, etc.) and where they submit
  • • SEO: Check URLs, meta titles, descriptions (use Yoast/RankMath export if available)
  • • E-commerce: If WooCommerce, document products, orders, customer data

💡 Pro tip: Create spreadsheet with all pages/posts, URLs, word counts. This becomes migration checklist. WordPress exports XML file - download this first (Tools → Export → All Content).

Export WordPress Content

WordPress has built-in export - use it:

  1. Log into WordPress admin
  2. Go to Tools → Export
  3. Choose "All Content" (posts, pages, media, etc.)
  4. Click "Download Export File" (XML file)
  5. Save this file - you'll need it for migration

💡 WordPress XML export = huge advantage. Contains all posts, pages, content, metadata. Most AI builders can't import this directly (need conversion), but having it means you don't lose content. Manual copy-paste from XML = faster than copying from live site.

Download All Media

Images don't export in WordPress XML - download separately:

  • • Media Library: Go to Media → Library, bulk download all images
  • • FTP/cPanel: Download /wp-content/uploads/ folder (faster for many images)
  • • Plugin method: Use "Media Export" plugin to bulk download
  • • Keep filenames: Maintain original filenames for SEO

💡 Pro tip: If you have 100+ images, use FTP/cPanel to download entire uploads folder at once. Much faster than right-clicking each image. Keep folder structure (year/month) if possible - helps organization.

STEP 2: CHOOSE TARGET AI BUILDER

Best AI Builders for WordPress Migrants

1. Framer (9/10 - Top Choice)

Why Framer for WordPress migrants:

  • • Best AI generation (rebuild site faster)
  • • Built-in blog CMS (import WordPress posts easily)
  • • Code export (freedom if you ever want to leave)
  • • Fast page load (vs. bloated WordPress)
  • • No plugins needed (forms, analytics, etc. built-in)

Cost: $15-40/month. Best overall for WordPress migrants.

2. Squarespace (8/10 - Easy Switch)

Why Squarespace for WordPress migrants:

  • • Built-in blog (WordPress-style blogging)
  • • Import tool (limited WordPress XML import)
  • • Beautiful templates (no theme hunting)
  • • All-in-one (no plugins ever needed)
  • • Easy to use (non-technical friendly)

Cost: $23-65/month. Best for non-technical users.

3. Webflow (8/10 - Designer Choice)

Why Webflow for WordPress migrants:

  • • Powerful CMS (better than WordPress for many)
  • • Custom collections (blog, case studies, products)
  • • Design freedom (no theme constraints)
  • • Code export (HTML/CSS freedom)
  • • No plugins (everything built-in or via embed)

Cost: $18-212/month. Best for designers/complex sites.

⚠️ PLATFORMS TO AVOID FOR WORDPRESS MIGRANTS

  • ❌ Mixo, Durable: Limited blog capabilities - not ideal if you have 50+ WordPress posts
  • ❌ Basic builders: Any platform without strong CMS - can't handle WordPress blog volume

💡 If your WordPress site has 20+ blog posts, choose platform with strong CMS (Framer, Squarespace, Webflow). Basic AI builders struggle with blog content volume.

STEP 3: MIGRATE CONTENT

Option A: WordPress Import Tool (Squarespace)

Squarespace offers limited WordPress import:

  1. In Squarespace: Go to Settings → Website → Import Content
  2. Choose WordPress: Select "WordPress" from import options
  3. Upload XML: Upload your WordPress export file
  4. Review imported content: Check posts, pages, images
  5. Manual cleanup: Fix formatting issues, adjust layout

💡 Squarespace import = 70% effective. Imports content but formatting breaks. Expect manual cleanup. Better than rebuilding from scratch, but not perfect.

Option B: Manual Migration (Framer, Webflow, Others)

Most AI builders require manual content migration:

  1. Build site structure first: Create pages in new platform (home, about, etc.)
  2. Copy content from WordPress: Open WordPress pages/posts, copy text
  3. Paste into new platform: Paste content into Framer/Webflow/etc.
  4. Recreate formatting: Apply headings, bold, links (doesn't transfer automatically)
  5. Upload images: Download from WordPress, upload to new platform
  6. Set up blog CMS: Create blog collection, import posts one-by-one
  7. Keep URL structure: Use same post slugs (/post-name) for SEO

💡 Manual migration = tedious but gives clean result. Budget 1-2 hours per 10 pages/posts. For 50-post blog: 10-15 hours total. Faster than rebuilding from scratch (20-30 hours).

Option C: Use Migration Service

Third-party services automate WordPress migration:

  • • BlogMigrator: Service that moves WordPress to various platforms
  • • ContentSnap: Automated content scraping and migration
  • • Fiverr/Upwork freelancers: Hire someone to migrate ($100-500 typical)

💡 Migration services cost $100-500 but save 10-20 hours. If you value time > $10-50/hour, consider hiring. For complex sites (100+ posts), service worth it. For simple sites (10-20 pages), DIY is fine.

STEP 4: PRESERVE SEO (CRITICAL!)

⚠️ SEO MIGRATION WARNING

Migrating from WordPress can DESTROY your SEO rankings if done wrong. URLs change, meta data lost, redirects missing = traffic drops 50-90%. WordPress typically has good SEO (plugins like Yoast/RankMath). AI builders = different SEO structure. Must migrate carefully or lose organic traffic. Here's how to preserve rankings:

Keep URL Structure Identical

Most important SEO rule:

  • • Match URL slugs exactly: If WordPress page is /about, new page must be /about
  • • Match blog post URLs: /2024/01/post-name in WordPress = same in new platform
  • • Category/tag URLs: If WordPress uses /category/name, replicate in new platform
  • • Why this matters: Google indexes URLs. Change URL = lost ranking = lost traffic

💡 If new platform doesn't support WordPress URL structure, set up 301 redirects from old URLs to new. This preserves 90-99% of ranking power. But keeping same URLs = no redirects needed = best approach.

Migrate Meta Data

WordPress SEO plugins store meta titles/descriptions - export these:

  • • Yoast SEO: Settings → Tools → Export → Export meta data
  • • RankMath: Tools → Export Settings → Choose meta data
  • • Manual method: Copy meta title/description from each page (slow but works)
  • • In new platform: Re-enter meta data for each page/post

💡 Meta data = critical for SEO. Title tags and descriptions = what shows in Google search results. Lose these = drop in rankings. Take time to migrate meta data properly. Worth the effort.

Set Up 301 Redirects (If URLs Must Change)

If you MUST change URLs, set up redirects:

  • • 301 redirect: "Permanently moved" - tells Google new location
  • • Preserves rankings: 90-99% of ranking power transferred
  • • Framer: Settings → Redirects → Add 301 redirects
  • • Webflow: Hosting → 301 Redirects → Add mappings
  • • Squarespace: Settings → Advanced → URL Mappings

💡 Best approach: Keep same URLs, avoid redirects entirely. But if platform limitations force URL changes, 301 redirects are mandatory. No redirects = massive traffic drop (50-90%).

STEP 5: TEST AND LAUNCH

Pre-Launch Checklist

  • ✅ All pages migrated: Every WordPress page has new version
  • ✅ All blog posts migrated: All articles present, formatting correct
  • ✅ All images loading: No broken images, optimized file sizes
  • ✅ URLs match old structure: Same slugs, no changes unless necessary
  • ✅ Meta data migrated: Titles, descriptions present for all pages/posts
  • ✅ Internal links work: Links between pages/posts function
  • ✅ Forms set up: Contact forms, comment forms functional
  • ✅ 301 redirects set: If URLs changed, redirects in place
  • ✅ Analytics installed: Google Analytics, Facebook Pixel
  • ✅ Mobile responsive: Test on phone, tablet

Launch Strategy

Minimize downtime and SEO impact:

  1. Build new site: Complete on temporary/preview URL
  2. Add domain: Add your domain to new platform (don't point yet)
  3. Backup WordPress: Full backup (files + database) just in case
  4. Choose launch time: Low-traffic time (Sunday 2am recommended)
  5. Update DNS: Change nameservers to point to new platform
  6. Wait for propagation: 1-48 hours for DNS update worldwide
  7. Monitor: Check Google Search Console for crawl errors
  8. Keep WordPress: Don't cancel hosting for 30 days (safety net)

💡 Keep old WordPress site active for 30 days. If something breaks, you can point domain back. Cancel old hosting only after new site is fully stable and all issues resolved.

Post-Migration: Cancel WordPress Properly

After 30 days of stable new site, cancel WordPress:

  • • Export final backup: One last complete backup for archives
  • • Cancel hosting: Cancel through hosting provider
  • • Cancel domain: If registered through host, transfer to new platform or separate registrar
  • • Cancel plugins: Cancel any plugin subscriptions
  • • Keep backups: Store WordPress backup offline (Google Drive, Dropbox) - might need years from now

💡 Never delete WordPress backup. Keep it forever. Years from now, you might need to reference old content, images, or data. Storage is cheap. Peace of mind = priceless.

WORDPRESS PLUGIN ALTERNATIVES IN AI BUILDERS

What About My WordPress Plugins?

Common WordPress plugins and their AI builder equivalents:

WordPress Plugin AI Builder Equivalent
Yoast SEO / RankMath Built-in SEO settings (meta tags, sitemaps)
Contact Form 7 / Gravity Forms Built-in form builders
Jetpack Built-in analytics, social sharing, security
Wordfence (security) Platform security (no plugin needed)
WooCommerce (e-commerce) Framer Commerce, Squarespace Commerce, Shopify integration
WP Rocket (caching) Built-in optimization (no caching needed)
Google Analytics Built-in analytics or simple embed code

💡 Most WordPress plugin functionality = built into AI builders. That's the beauty: no plugins, no updates, no conflicts. Everything just works. This is why people migrate - simplify from 50+ plugins to 0 plugins.

BOTTOM LINE

💡 MY RECOMMENDATION

Migrating from WordPress to AI builder = smart move for most people. Escape plugin hell, constant updates, security worries. Choose Framer (9/10) for best AI + code export freedom. Squarespace (8/10) for non-technical users. Webflow (8/10) for designers. Plan migration thoroughly: export WordPress content, keep URL structure, preserve meta data, test everything before pointing domain. Budget 20-40 hours for DIY migration or pay $100-500 for service. Post-migration: Cancel all WordPress plugin subscriptions, keep backups forever. Result: Simpler, faster, more secure website. No more plugin conflicts. No more update anxiety. Just website that works. Freedom.

QUICK SUMMARY

67% of WordPress users migrate to AI builders within 2 years.

Why: Plugin hell, updates, security, maintenance.

Result: Simpler, faster, no plugins, peace of mind.

WordPress = Free software, $1000s in time/plugins.
AI builders = Predictable cost, zero maintenance. Choose freedom.
